description: Plants grow up to 50cm. Annual with deep red, anemone-like flower with central black spot and black anthers. Bright green, finely divided leaves. Elongated oval seed head bears approximately 30 olive-green seeds, similar in shape to a grape pip. This plant does not seem to be able to survive in areas with high application of nitrogen fertiliser, or compete against nitrophilous crops that quickly out-compete and shade out its seedlings.
conservation_status: Endangered (applies to natural populations from the soil seed bank)

description: Hairy, erect plant, up to 100cm tall. Long, narrow and undivided leaves, which taper to a point. Flowers are large (2-5cm across) and trumpet-shaped, bright pink with dark streaks and occur singly on long stems. There are very few natural populations originating from the soil seed bank and corncockle is often included in annual seed mixtures. The seeds are short-lived, rot very quickly in damp weather, and may not survive the first winter after being shed from the plant. This species was originally spread as a contaminant in crop seeds, and improved seed cleaning has resulted in a strong decline, with remaining populations being critically endangered.
seed_longevity: Very short-lived (less than one year) unless deeply-buried where it may survive dormant for longer
conservation_status: Critically Endangered (applies to natural populations from the soil seed bank)

description: Small plant, not exceeding 5-20cm height. Often sprawling and shaped like a tiny pine tree, with a reddish stem, long, narrow, hairy green leaves (often tinged yellow through to red) and little yellow flowers nestling close to the stem. Flowers and bruised leaves smell of pine-resin. Individuals often appear after deep ground disturbance along hedges, but do not grow  in very shaded or crowded swards.

Up to 60cm tall, growing as annual or biennial. Plant bristly, and bristles with swollen bases. Lower leaves with long stalks, kidney-shaped, bluntly five-lobed. Leaves further up the stem are deeply cut and have only short stalks. Characteristic mallow flowers 2.c in diameter are pale pink, with scarcely notched petals. Outer sepal ring forming a lobed cup. Rough marsh-mallow is often found adjacent to field boundaries and can be a sprawling plant climbing up through open vegetation. Plants on thinner soils tend to be smaller and short-lived, whilst those on deeper soils are more vigorous.
germination_period: Autumn and spring (flowering the following year)

description: Erect plant, up to 30cm tall, and branched from the base. Leaves are spear-shaped, narrower at the base and covered with minute star-shaped hairs. The flowers are borne in a terminal spike and are small with four yellow petals, which fade to white as they dry.

Scrambling mat-forming plant with stems up to 30cm long. The leaves are arranged in opposite pairs, are stalkless  and oval, and up to 20mm long by 9mm wide. The five blue petals are approximately 10mm in diameter, and do not overlap, thereby showing the sepal between the petals. The flower stalks are shorter than the leaves. The petals have short hairs 4 cells (sections) in length.
confusion: Can be confused with blue-flowered variant of Anagallis arvensis ssp. arvensis

description: Erect bristly plant, 15-40cm tall. The bristles have bulbous bases. Wavy-edged spear-shaped leaves 15cm long are stalked at the base of the stem, and clasp the stem further up the plant. Light sky-blue flowers are grouped together at the top of the stem, or arise from the top leaf junctions.
soil: Well-drained sandy loams, calcareous chalks, limestone, clays and neutral loams.

description: Branched mayweed, up to 50cm tall. Alternate, deeply divided leaves are slightly flattened. The typical daisy-like flowers have white ray-florets and yellow disc-florets. At the base of the latter, a scale is attached to the flower receptacle. Leaves of corn chamomile smell aromatically of chamomile when crushed. Disc floret scales are 2.5mm long by 1mm wide, broaden to about two-thirds of their length, and taper to a point.
management:

description: Branched mayweed, up to 50cm tall. Alternate, deeply divided leaves are slightly flattened. The typical daisy-like flowers have white ray-florets and yellow disc-florets. At the base of the latter,  a scale is attached to the flower receptacle. Leaves of stinking chamomile smell unpleasant when crushed. The flowers tend to be slightly smaller than those of corn chamomile, whereas receptacular scales are similar-sized, but narrow,  with linear sides tapering to a point.
management:

description: Annual plant, up to 20 cm tall. Culms often branched. Leaves blades 2-4 mm wide and up to 5cm long and hairless, but with tufts of long hair where leaf blade and stem meet. Spikelets (5-7mm long) have long and conspicuous bent awns and are gathered into a pale-green terminal flower spike. Annual vernal grass was probably introduced in crop seed, and its decline appears to be due at least partly to improved seed-cleaning.

Downy plant, up to 50cm tall. The stems are hollow and hairless, but the finely branched leaves have tiny (5mm) pale-green leaflets. The white flowers are 2mm across and arranged in umbels. The seeds are 3mm long, oval-shaped and covered with hooked spines.
soil: Acid-neutral sandy loams and gravelly soils.

description: Erect annual grass, up to 70cm tall. Leave blades can grow up to 10cm long and 4mm wide, and are mostly hairless. Each leaf has a long pointed ligule, up to 5mm long. The flowers are arranged in a loose interrupted spike with stalkless branches. Each spikelet has a very long straight awn. This species was originally introduced as a seed contaminant from wool shoddy and has declined because of targeted graminicide use and the planting of highly competitive fertilised crops.

Erect annual grass, up to 100cm tall. Leave blades can grow up to 20cm long by 10mm wide and can be rough. Each leaf has a long pointed and toothed ligule that is up to 1cm long. Flower spikes are finely branched and spreading widely, up to 20cm long and 15cm wide. Each spikelet has a long awn. Loose silky-bent has declined because of targeted graminicide use.

Low-growing plant of 2-20 cm height. Fan-shaped leaves have three deeply-toothed main lobes, and are 2-10mm long. Minute flowers less than 2mm in diameter are present in leaf axils and are hidden by the larger green leaf stipules. The stipule lobes are oblong-shaped. unlike those of the closely related parsley-piert Aphanes arvensis, which are triangular.

A member of the daisy family growing up to 30cm tall. The hairless elliptical leaves form a rosette at the bottom of the leafless flowering stem. The yellow flowers are 7-11mm in diameter and are borne singly at the end of each branch of the stem. Flowering stems are inflated just below the flower heads. Although this plant can look similar to other yellow-flowering members of the daisy family, such as dandelions, hawkbits, cat's-ears and hawkweeds, the inflated stem under each flower is distinctive. Lamb's-succory is unable to persist in highly nitrogen-fertilised environments, and the marginal low-intensity arable fields that it did occupy have been abandoned for cultivation.
seed_longevity: Unknown but seeds last for at least three years in the soil seed bank

description: Erect grass, up to 120cm tall. The blunt and slightly toothed ligule at the base of each leaf blade is 1.5-5mm, and leaf blades are broad and flat tapering to a point much like those of other oat grasses. Flowers are often loosely nodding to one side of the flower spike, with each spikelet bearing two flowers of 16-26mm length. The lemmas have two teeth, each with a bristle, and there is an awn on both lemmas from the middle of the back. There is no obvious callus scar on the florets when they are separated and they do not shatter easily, which hinders the establishment of populations. Bristle oat was originally grown as a cereal crop in poorer soils in the North and West of Britain, but has since been replaced by modern varieties of cultivated oat Avena sativa.

Member of the cabbage family, up to 100cm tall. Lower leaves are bristly and bright-green, lyre-shaped and lobed. Upper leaves are hairless, elliptical and undivided, and do not clasp the stem. The 10-15mm large yellow flowers are grouped in a loose raceme at the top of the flowering stem. The seed pods are adpressed, four-angled and 12-20mm long. A seedless slender beak extends at the end of the seed pod.
soil: Acidic sandy loams and sands, silty and clay loams.
management:

description: Erect grass, up to 50cm tall. Leaves are 3-7mm wide, hairless and blue-green in colour, with a pointed ligule 3-6mm long. The branched infloresecence has triangular flower spikelets. The plant looks like a smaller version of common quaking-grass Briza media, which tends to be associated with calcareous grasslands. Lesser quaking-grass tends to grow in slightly damp areas of fields where water has pooled, suppressing other plants and creating bare ground.
soil: Acidic sands, loams, gravels and clays.

description: Robust grass, up to 100cm tall. Leaves and stem are softly-densely hairy. The leaves have a blunt ligule up to 4mm long, and leaf blades can be up to 20cm long by 5mm wide. The flower spike is very branched and drooping, with long-stalked spikelets that are laterally compressed and 1.5cm long by 4mm wide. The lemma is inrolled, stopping the spikelets from breaking-up easily, and less than 6.5mm long, with a rough straight awn up to 1cm long. Field brome probably relied on being spread as a contaminant of crop seed, and more effective seed cleaning may have been responsible for its decline.

Up to 100cm tall grass. Leaves and stem are softly-densely hairy. Leaves are 20cm long by 5mm wide, and have a blunt ligule up to 4mm long. The flower spike is branched, with very short spikelet stalks that are grouped into clusters of three. The spikelets are oval,slightly laterally compressed, and 1-1.7cm long. The lemma has a rough straight awn up to 8mm long. Interrupted brome is very poorly competitive and cannot compete against modern crop varieties grown with nitrogen fertilisers.
soil: Usually clay loams and occasionally other soil types.

description: Erect grass up to 1m tall. Leaves are 5mm wide and up to 25cm long, with blunt ligules up to 4mm long. The stem and leaf are softly hairy. The branched flower-head has long-stalked oval spikelets that are slightly laterally compressed. The inrolled lemma stops the spikelets breaking-up and shedding when ripe, keeping the seeds in a spikelet form until much later in the summer than in other species of brome.
soil: Calcareous clays loams and occasionally other soil types.
management:

description: A member of the carrot family, up to 60cm tall. This perennial plant over-winters as an underground tuber formed at the base of the stem. The finely three-pinnately divided leaves appear feathery. The white flowers are grouped in umbels 3-8cm across. Greater pignut has a solid stem compared with pignut Conopodium majus, which has a hollow stem. This species requires occasional disturbance of field edge habitats every other year.

Distinctive member of the carrot family, up to 75cm tall, which looks more like a member of the spurge family. The stem is reddish and branched. Leaves are round-oval, with upper leaves completely fused around the stem. The small greenish-yellow flowers are clustered in small umbels at the end of the stems, and these umbels are cupped by a ring of green petal-like bracteoles. Thorow-wax has not been found in the wild since 1973.

description: Member of the mustard family, up to 120cm tall. The lanceolate leaves are arranged alternately up the stem which can become woody with age. The pale-yellow flowers, like those of other members of the mustard family, have four petals. The seeds, which are of a distinctive orange colour, are borne in pear-shaped seed pods. False flax is often included in bird seed mixtures.
conservation_status: Nationally Scarce (applies to natural populations from the soil seed bank)

description: Member of the carrot family, up to 30cm tall. The short leaves are three-pinnately divided and look feathery. Bristles are randomly scattered throughout the plant. Each umbel flower head has 2-5 branches and large seeds are formed in pairs, splitting apart as they are shed from the plant. The seeds have distinctive long curved spines and are up to 13mm long. This plant has declined in response to the introduction of competitive crop varieties and the increased use of nitrogen fertilisers and of herbicides. Having probably been spread with crop seed in traditional farming, it may also have partly declined in response to improved methods of seed cleaning.
seed_longevity: Unknown but seeds last for at least three years in the soil seed bank

description: Usually branched, and up to 1m tall. Leaves are grey-green and hairy. Lower leaves variably dissected, narrow, and 10-20cm in length; upper leaves smaller and un-dissected. The blue flower heads are up to 3cm in diameter.
soil: Sandy soils but may be present on calcareous clays and chalk.
seed_longevity: Short-lived seed unless deeply-buried where it may survive dormant for longer
conservation_status: Endangered (applies to natural populations from the soil seed bank)

description: Smallish plant, maximum height 20cm. The narrow parallel-sided leaves are arranged alternately up the stem. Solitary flower stalks are borne in leaf axils. Flowers 6-9mm long and asymmetrical, purple outside and paler inside, and with a short spur.

Tall plant, up to 100cm tall. Plant, and in particular young leaves, mealy. The leaves are three-lobed and hairless, and resemble fig-leaves. The flower spike has clusters of small florets of 2mm size.

description: Up to 100cm tall. The plant is not mealy. Leaves are hairless, cordate at the base, and with a few large acute triangular teeth, making them resemble maple-leaves. The flower spike has clusters of small florets of 2mm size.
management:

Conservation headlands

description: Erect annual, up to 100cm tall. Stem red-streaked, mealy. Inflorescences in loose leafless clusters with powdery appearance. The flowers are petal-less and have yellow stamens and tiny green, minutely-toothed sepals. Leaves are sharp-toothed and diamond-shaped, with smooth upper surface and powdery underside.
soil: Light sandy loams and clay soils.

soil: Light sandy loams and clay soils.

soil: Light sandy loams and clay soils.

description: Annual plant, up to 60cm tall. Leaves are three-pinnate with linear segments. The stem and lower leaves are grey, with star-shaped adpressed hairs. flowers small, pale-yellow. fruits elongated, 1.5-2.5cm long by 1mm wide, curving upwards on slender stalks. The caterpillars of Grey Carpet moth <i>Lithostege griseata<i> feed on the developing seeds of flixweed.

This biennial species grows up to 75cm tall and is covered in bristly hairs. The leaves are narrowly oval, forming a rosette at the base of the stem, also occurring along the stem. The large purple flowers are borne on a branched spike. The petals are fused into a tube, with two projecting stamens, and hair confined to the veins and petal margins. For comparison, the more common viper's-bugloss Echium vulgare has smaller, hairy flowers and each of its flowers has 4-5 stamens. Purple viper's-bugloss can be a contaminant of bird seed mixtures. Individuals re-grow from stubbles, flowering again after harvest.
soil: Sandy loams and rarely other soils.
conservation_status: Near Threatened (applies to natural populations from the soil seed bank)

description: This spreading plant can grow up to 30cm tall. All of the plant may be hairy, and can feel sticky. The long leaves are made up of toothed leaflets arising in opposite pairs along the midrib,  with an additional terminal leaflet. Leaves with pointed whitish stipules at the base. Flowers less than 10mm in diameter. Groups of 7-10 flowers at the end of the flowering stem. The five rose-purple to white petals are unequal and 6-8mm long.

This spreading plant can grow up to 60cm tall and smells of musk. All of the plant may be hairy and is very sticky.  The long leaves are made up of shallowly toothed leaflets arising in opposite pairs along the midrib,  with an additional terminal leaflet. leaves with broad and blunt whitish stipules at the base. Flowers about 15mm in diameter. Groups of 2-8 flowers at the end of the flowering stem. The five rose-purple to white petals are  unequal and 6-8mm long. Musk stork's-bill struggles to grow in stands of competitive crops and is usually found on bare ground, or in very short grassland.

Member of the cabbage family, up to 100cm tall. Leaves are spear-shaped, with shallow teeth, and are mostly found in the lower half of the square stem. The small yellow flowers have four petals and are arranged in terminal flower spikes. Each flower develops into a narrow seed pod growing away from the stem at an upward angle.
soil: Sandy and chalky loams but may be found in calcareous clays.

description: Up to 10 cm tall. Plant light-green, hairless. The narrow, parallel-sided leaves can be up to 2cm long by 3mm wide. Flowers are yellowish-green and without petals, and are arranged in a loose umbel with a leafy bract at the base. Fruits are smooth, spherical capsules that explode on ripening.
soil: Sands, calcareous loams and clays, chalk and limestone soils.

description: Up to 60 cm tall. Plant green, hairless, with often reddish stems. Leaves are broad, narrowly-oblong and pointed, with serrated edges, and up to 5cm long. Flowers are yellowish-green and without petals,  and arranged in a loose umbel with a leafy bract at the base. Fruits are approximately 3mm in diameter and covered with warts. They explode on ripening.

Slender plant, up to 25cm tall, but often shorter. Stems may be branched from the base, and the whole plant appears grey due to fine hairs covering the stems and leaves. Leaves are up to 18mm long, pointed and fine. The grey and woolly flowers are clustered together in dense flower-heads at the top of stems. Narrow-leaved cudweed has been known from around 30 sites in Essex and Suffolk, with the last record in 1955 located near Colchester. In these counties, it has been reintroduced at some sites, but it is thought to be extinct elsewhere.

Annual plant, up to 25cm tall. Plant grey-green, sometimes with a yellow tinge. Stems usually branched. Topmost leaves usually overtopping the terminal clusters of flowers. Flowers clustered and with minute, red-tipped bristles. Often confused with common cudweed Filago vulgaris which lacks red tips and has slightly narrower leaves that do not overtop the flowers.

Up to 30cm tall. Plant silvery-green. Flower heads at the end of short stems are made up of of 8-15 tiny flowers, and appear as a cluster of tiny pyramids formed of grey scales. Leaves are wider towards the top, have rounded tips, and overtop the terminal flower clusters.
soil: Calcareous chalk, limestone and sands. Historically it grew in acidic sands and gravels.

description: Erect and often well-branched plant, wooly due to a covering of silvery-grey hair, and up to 50 cm tall. Leaves 10-20mm long,  strap-shaped, wavy-edged and blunt-tipped. The topmost leaves on the stem do not overtop the globular flower cluster at the top of the stem. Tiny florets within terminal flower clusters  hidden behind several rows of bracts, with outer bracts being short, densely woolly, and straight-pointed, and inner bracts being  longer, bristle-shaped, and yellowish-tipped.
soil: Acid and calcareous sandy soils, loams and chalk.

description: Scrambling, much-branched plant. Leaves blue-green and  irregularly divided almost down to the midrib, with narrow blunt lobes. The leaf segments are relatively broad and flat. Flowers in groups of 10-18, arranged in racemes at several points along the stem, opposite the leaves. Asymmetrical flowers with fused petals forming a tube, but separating at the tip. Each flower is 9-11mm long, pale salmon-pink with only the mid-petal tipped darker purple at the end. Sepals present on both sides of the flower at the junction of stem and flower  are small, toothed, and white, and 3mm long by 1.5mm wide. Each flower produces a spherical fruit 2-2.4mm in diameter, and fruit stalks are never recurved.

description: Scrambling, much-branched plant. Leaves blue-green and  irregularly divided almost down to the midrib, with narrow blunt lobes. The leaf segments are relatively broad and flat. Flowers arranged in racemes at several points along the stem, opposite the leaves. Racemes are shorter than their stalks, and contain around 20 flowers. The sepals are small, toothed at the base, white, and 4-6mm long by 2.5-3mm wide. Each flower produces a spherical fruit 2mm in diameter, and the stalks are strongly recurved.

description: Scrambling, much-branched plant. Leaves blue-green and  irregularly divided almost down to the midrib, with narrow blunt lobes. The leaf segments are channelled and very narrow. Flowers arranged in racemes at several points along the stem, opposite the leaves, and contain around 20-25 flowers. Asymmetrical flowers with fused petals forming a tube, but separating at the tip.  Each flower is 6-7mm long, pink-red, with purple-black tipped petals. The sepals are white and large in comparison to the flower, being 2mm long by 3mm wide. Each flower produces a spherical fruit 2mm in diameter.
soil: Chalk loams and occasionally coastal sands, calcareous clays and sandy loams.

description: Large-flowered fumitory. Blue-green leaves with relatively broad and channelled leaf segments. Asymmetrical flowers with fused petals forming a tube, but separating at the tip. Flowers 9-11mm long, pinkish-red, with darker red tipped petals. Racemes each with 8-20 flowers, and longer than their stalks. Sepals pale, toothed mainly at the base, and half the length of the flower, 2.7-3mm long by 1.5-2mm wide. Fruits are spherical with a rounded apex. Each flower produces a spherical fruit 2mm in diameter.

description: The most vigorous species of ramping-fumitory, scrambling and much branched. The blue-green leaves are broad and flat and irregularly divided. Asymmetrical flowers with fused petals forming a tube, but separating at the tip. Flowers are 12-15mm long and initially white, becoming pink with age. The tips of the petals are blackish-red. Each flower raceme contains 12-20 flowers, and racemes are the same length as their stalks.  Sepals are white, toothed at the base, and 5mm long by 3mm wide.  This species is endemic to Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly.

A typical fumitory with blue-green leaves that are irregularly divided into very narrow and channelled segments. Asymmetrical flowers with fused petals forming a tube, but separating at the tip. Flowers are 5-6mm long and white, with reddish-black tipped petals. Each raceme contains around 16-20 flowers. Sepals are white, irregularly toothed, and small, being only 1mm by 0.8mm wide. Fruits are spherical, sometimes with short beak at the apex.

Flowers are 10-13mm long and pinkish-purple, with petals tipped darker purple. Racemes contain around 20-25 flowers, and are the same length as their stalk.  Sepals are white, toothed, oblong, and half the length of the flower, being 6mm long by 3mm wide. As fruits ripen, their stalks can become gently-recurved. Fruits are squarish in shape, and 2.5mm in diameter.

description: Large-flowered fumitory, Blue-green leaves with relatively broad and flat leaf segments. Asymmetrical flowers with fused petals forming a tube, but separating at the tip. Flowers are 11-13mm long and pink, with blackish-red tipped petals. Racemes contain 15-20 flowers and are longer than their stalk.  Sepals are white, with very few teeth, and 4mm long by 2.5mm wide. Each flower produces a single spherical fruit 2.5mm in diameter. Martin's ramping-fumitory is very restricted in distribution and has only been found at 14 sites in southern England, most of which have been allotments.

description: Member of the mint family, up to 50cm tall. Leaves shallowly-toothed, softly-hairy, and spear-shaped, up to 1.5cm long by less than 1cm wide. Flowers relatively large and asymmetrical, with hooded upper lip, large three-lobed lower lip, and very long corolla tube. Flowers are densely clustered in leaf axils. Petals pinkish-red with white patches, and each flower producing four seeds. Red hemp-nettle has declined through the use of broad-spectrum herbicides, the planting of more competitive crop varieties, an increase in fertiliser application, and a shift from spring cultivation to autumn cultivation.
soil: Light chalky and sandy soils and coastal shingle.
flowering_period: July - September, some regrowth and flowering in cereal stubbles

description: A typical fumitory with blue-green leaves whose leaf segments are relatively flat. Asymmetrical flowers with fused petals forming a tube, but separating at the tip. Flowers are 5-6mm long and pale pink, with reddish-black tipped petals. Racemes contain around 6-16 loosely arranged flowers, and are longer than their stalk. Sepals pale purple, toothed, and very small, being 1mm long by 0.5mm wide. Fruits are spherical, rounded at the apex, and 2mm in diameter.

description: Member of the mint family, up to 50cm tall. Stems are not thickened at the leaf nodes. Leaves shallowly-toothed, softly-hairy, spear-shaped, and up to 8cm long by 3cm wide. Flowers sulphur-yellow, 2.5cm in length, with asymmetrical petals formed into a tube, with a large lower lip at the opening. Lower lip with a bright yellow tongue. Downy hemp-nettle was historically found in central England, but its last record in the UK was in north Wales in 1975.

Member of the mint family, up to 1m tall, branched. Nettle-like ovate leaves are shallowly toothed, and 2.5-8cm long. Flowers asymmetrical and large, with hooded and hairy upper lip, large three-lobed lower lip, and a very long corolla tube of up to 3cm length. Petals pale yellow, with a large violet patch on the lower lip. Each flower produces four seeds.

description: Scrambling and climbing plant, up to 100cm tall. Similar to common cleavers Galium aparine, but with shorter and narrower leaves. Flowers are greenish-white, 1mm across and the flowering/fruiting stalk is straight. Fruits are less than 3mm across, blackish when ripe, and covered with with hooked bristles. Note that the bases of these bristles are not swollen, a feature distinguishing this species from common cleavers Galium aparine.

Sprawling plant, with 4-angled prickly stems. Leaves linear to lanceolate and in whorls. Flowers cream-coloured, 1-1.5mm across, and grouped in sets of three. Fruits similarly occurring in groups of three, and covered with minute projections rather than with hooked bristles, with stalks strongly arched downwards. Very similar to false cleavers Galium spurium which are darker green. Corn cleavers has declined due to seed cleaning, increased use nitrogen fertilisers, and planting of more competitive crop varieties.

Erect, tufted grass, up to 50cm tall. The leaf blades are up to 10cm long by 4mm wide, with a short ligule at the base. Flower heads are spear shaped, tapering to a point. The lemmas have a bent awn which is up to 4mm long. Nit-grass has declined due to targeted use of graminicides, increased use of nitrogen fertilisers, and planting of competitive crop varieties. In recent years, it has increased in set-aside land.
soil: Thin limestone soils and well-drained calcareous clays prone to drought.

description: Slender annual, up to 40cm tall. Leaves on long stalks, approximately pentagonal in outline, and divided nearly to the base into into 5-7 narrow main lobes which themselves are deeply sublobed, making the leaf similar in shape to a pigeon's foot. Flowers pink, with unnotched petals about 7-9mm long, and at the end of 2-6 cm long flower stalks. Fruits hairless and unwrinkled.

Spreading plant with downy stems and leaves. The leaves are round in outline with 7-9 lobes, divided one-half to two-thirds to the base. Petals dingy mauve, notched, and 2-4mm long. Fruits are downy and smooth. Small-flowered crane's-bill can easily be confused with dove's-foot crane's-bill Geranium molle which has hairless and wrinkled seeds.
soil: Sandy soils, and calcareous clays and loams.

description: Plant up to 60cm tall, usually well-branched. Leaves 2-10 cm long, greyish-green in colour, with a waxy surface. Lower leaves lobed or coarsely toothed, narrowed into a winged stalk. Upper leaves toothed only or more or less entire, stalkless and clasping around the stem. Flowers orangey-yellow, with disc florets producing cylindrical unwinged seeds and ray florets producing broad-winged seeds.
soil: Sandy soils which may be acid or calcareous where they are derived from shell-sand.

description: Up to 30cm tall. Leaves ovate-lanceolate, up to 2cm long and 5-6mm wide, and arranged in opposite pairs along the stem. Clusters of 5-10 flowers  at the end of the stem, with different-lengthed individual flower stalks. Flowers have five white petals and five sepals, the latter with a membraneous margin.

Up to 80cm tall. Bristly-stemmed, annual or biennial. Leaves oval-oblong and toothed, glaucous-green, sticky-haired, and strong-smelling. The upper leaves may clasp the stem. Along flowering stems, two rows of flowers are present, flowering in succession, with new buds forming at the top of the stem. Flowers are dull-yellow, with purple veins and a purple centre. The whole plant is very poisonous.
soil: Sandy soils, and light chalk and limestone soils.

description: Dandelion-like annual with a rosette of leaves and flowering stem up to 40cm tall. The scales on the flowering stem are shaped like cats' ears. Leaves  usually hairless, 1-8cm long, toothed to lobed, and narrowly spear-shaped, with the thin end at the base. Flower heads open wide only in full sunlight, and have bright yellow ray florets made up of single large petals twice as long as wide.

Erect plant with a branched stem, up to 40cm tall. Lower leaves spoon-shaped, narrowing into a stalk-like base. Upper leaves also broader near the tip than the base, but not narrowing as much towards the base, with 2-4 blunt teeth. Flowers in open clusters at the ends of branches, with each flower having four white (or lilac) petals of unequal size. Fruits circular with projecting wings that are triangular lobe-shaped and distinguish the species from other members of the cabbage family. Wild candytuft has declined due to more agriculturally intensive management of field margins.

Long-stemmed and prostrate creeping plant, with many branching stems and occasionally forming mats. Leaves are hairly and arranged alternately up the stem. Basal leaves are round, whereas leaves further up the stem are triangular-shaped, with teeth at the bottom projecting sideways, giving them the shape of an arrow-head. Flowers asymmetrical, yellow with a purple upper lip. Flowers are borne solitarily on long stalks originating in leaf axils. Flower stalks only hairy directly underneath flower.
soil: Well-drained calcareous soils, loams and sandy soils.

description: Long-stemmed and prostrate creeping plant, with many branching stems and occasionally forming mats. Leaves are hairy and arranged alternatively up the stem. Basal leaves are round, and leaves further up the stem are round to oval. The leaves tend to be larger than those produced by sharp-leaved fluellen Kickxia elatine. Flowers asymmetrical, yellow with a purple upper lip. Flowers are borne solitarily on long stalks originating in leaf axils. Flower stalks hairy throughout.
soil: Well-drained calcareous soils, loams and clay soils.

description: Irregularly-branched plant, low-growing, up to 30cm tall. Leaves more or less round, irregularly-toothed , and arranged in opposite pairs up the square stem. Lower leaves with short stalks, upper leaves stalkless and clasping the stem. Flowers pinkish-purple, asymmetrical, borne in whorls of up to 10 in leaf axils and at the end of the stem. Flowers are 1.4-2cm long, with lower lips <3mm long. Each flower produces four seeds.
soil: Present on a wide variety of soils, especially well drained calcareous loams.

description: Member of the pea family, scrambling and up to 40cm tall. Plant waxy grey-green. In mature plants, leaves are reduced to tendrils and functionally replaced by enlarged stipules. These are triangular and borne in pairs along the stem. Flowers yellow, borne singly at the end of long stalks. Seed pods 2-4cm long.

Up to 25cm tall, but often smaller. Stem with short hairs. Leaves stalkless, oval, with wavy edges and up to 1.5cm long. Flowers purple, with five petals, up to 1cm across when fully open and close when the sun is not shining. Sepals green, longer than the petals. The distinctive fruit capsule is up to 3cm long by 4mm wide and almost cylindrical in shape.

description: Up to 40cm tall. Stem hairless. Large five-petalled purple flowers are 2.5cm across and close when the sun is not shining. Each flower has a white centre. Sepals green, as long as the petals. The distinctive fruit capsule is up to 1.5cm in length by 4mm wide. There is only one known field with greater Venus's-looking-glass in Hampshire.

Up to 60 cm tall, growing as an annual or biennial. Plant softly hairy. Basal leaves lyre-shaped, soon withering. Stem leaves triangular, toothed, and stalkless, with clasping pointed basal lobes. Flowers white, inconspicuous, 2-2.5mm in diameter, and arranged in long racemes. Fruits are 5mm x 4 mm in size, covered in minute bumps which are visible when using a hand lens, and have a short style not projecting above the fruit notch.
soil: Dry sandy and gravelly soils, brown loams.

description: Up to 80cm tall plant, found scrambling amongst crops. Plant covered in short bristles. Leaves grey-green, narrow and pointed. Flowers small, white, found where the uppermost leaves join the stem. Each flower produces 4 warty pale-brown seeds. Field gromwell is susceptible to many herbicides. Recently, field gromwell has been found to be a good source of omega 3 and omega 6 fatty acids, and it is now grown as a crop, using imported seed from continental Europe.

Annual grass, up to 100cm tall. Culms growing in tufts or solitary. Leaves hairless, up to 40cm long, and with a blunt ligule 2mm long. Each flower spikelet is 12-20mm long by 4-6mm wide, and enclosed in a glume longer than the rest of the flower. Lemmas may have straight rough awns up to 2cm long, but may be awnless. Darnel is thought to have declined due to improved cleaning of crop seed.
soil: Can live in a wide range of soils.

description: Low-growing spreading plant with a branched stem, up to 20cm tall. Leaves stalkless. Basal leaves oval, with leaves further up the stem becoming increasingly narrower and more linear. Flowers borne singly in leaf axels along the stem, with six pink petals. Grass-poly has specialised ecological requirements and is only found in areas that are wet in winter, remaining crop-free as the stubble dies due to water-logging, and that dry out in the summer.

Creeping, downy plant, 15-60cm tall. Leaves kidney-shaped to roundish, with 5-7 very shallow lobes. Flowers clustered along the stem, with five whitish petals. Petals 8-13mm long, with lilac veins. The fruit is segmented and smooth.

Up to 150cm tall plant, growing as annual or biennial. Very similar to common mallow Malva sylvestris, but distinguished from the latter by the outer sepal-ring of the flower forming a lobed cup. Leaves are a paler green, less lobed and smooth, than those of common mallow. Flowers five-petalled, pink-lilac.

Downy, aromatic herb with a 'peppery' mint smell when bruised, 10-30cm tall. Leaves are round-elliptical and blunt-tipped, and arranged in opposite pairs up the stem. Dense whorls of flowers are present in the leaf axils. The calyx of each flower is bell-shaped and very hairy, with short triangular teeth. Petals are mauve. Stamens project from the flower.

description: Erect plant with branching stems, up to 60cm tall. Leaves, glossy-green, spear-shaped and stalkless, often with a few teeth at the base. Flowers bright-coloured, borne in dense, cylindrical, terminal spikes, and with a yellow corolla-tube and two mainly purple-pink lips above a strongly toothed pinkish-red bract. Field cow-wheat has declined due to improved cleaning of crop seed and more intensive agriculture along field margins. It is partially parasitic on a range of other flowering plants.
soil: Thin soils over chalk and calcareous clays.

description: Plant up to 50cm tall, hairless, with one or several flowering stems. Foliage pale shiny-green. Leaves 2-5cm long, toothed. This species is, i.e. plants are either female or male, with either  male catkins on stalks or bristly stalkless female fruits growing from the leaf axils. Annual mercury is often found on slightly nutrient-enriched soil.

Upper leaves pointed and unstalked, with the leaf base clasping the stem, which thus appears to perforate the leaf, hence the name 'perfoliate'. \Flowers white, four-petalled, and arranged in clusters at the top of stems. Fruits 4mm long by 5mm wide, heart-shaped and flattened, with membranous wings along each edge. Perfoliate penny-cress has always been rare in arable habitats.

Stalkless, asymmetrical flowers that are borne in leaf axils. Flowers deep-pink, with a slight yellow tinge in the flower tube, and resembling those of the garden snapdragon.

description: Distinctive member of the buttercup family, 2-15cm tall. Leaves dark-green, narrow, linear, forming a basal rosette, with leafless flowering stems growing from the centre. The flower spikes have short-lived, small green-yellow petals below the seed-bearing receptacle. This receptacle elongates, forming a long, narrowly-conical tube which resembles a mouse's tail. Mousetail occurs on water-retentive soils in disturbed areas such as tracks and hollows, particularly in gateways.
soil: Clays and other silty soils which are non-calcareous.

description: Mint-like aromatic perennial, up to 100cm tall. Stem and leaves covered with a grey down. Leaves greyish-green, heart-shaped and toothed. Flowers white with purplish spots.

A parasitic plant which grows attached to the roots of various host plants. Leaves reduced to scales and plant without chlorophyll. Instead of being green, the plant is a purplish colour. It consists of a single flower spike with tube-like flowers. Flowers have a yellow corolla with purple veins. The back of the corolla is arched in a smooth curve. Stigma lobes can be relatively variable. being fully parasitic, this plant relies on the presence of other vegetation, and is for example found in grassy field margins. The British flora contains other species of broomrape, but these tend to be far less common.

Up to 50cm tall. Basal rosettes of leaves with stems growing from the centre. Leaves pinnately divided, with narrow, parallel-sided segments, and can appear flattened. Flowering stems can branch at the base but more commonly the main stem is branched, with each branch bearing a single terminal flower. Flowers are up to 5cm across and made up of four orange-red petals, which are dropped after just a single day of flowering. The stamens have bright blue pollen. The characteristic seed head is elongated and club-shaped, 2-2.5cm long, and covered by numerous prickles and a terminal disc.
soil: Predominantly chalky and sandy loams, sometimes calcareous clays.

description: Up to 60cm tall. Basal rosette of leaves with branched stems growing from the centre. Leaves blue-green coloured, pinnately divided into broad, spear-shaped segments. Flowers are 5cm across and made up of four petals which are pinkish-red and unblotched. The seed capsule is elongated without prickles, similar to the capsule of long-headed poppy Papaver dubium. Yellow-juiced poppy can be reliably distinguished from long-headed poppy based on the colour of its latex which turns yellow on contact with air.

Up to 50cm tall. Basal rosettes of leaves with stems growing from the centre. Leaves are pinnately divided, with narrow, parallel-sided segments, and can appear flattened. Flowering stems can branch at the base, but more commonly, the main stem is branched, with each branch bearing a single terminal flower. Flowers are up to 5cm across and made up of four scarlet petals that have black blotches at their base. The stamens have deep-blue pollen. The seed head is  spherical, 1-1.5cm in diameter, and covered with numerous upward pointing prickles and a terminal disc.
soil: Predominantly chalky and sandy loams, sometimes calcareous clays.

description: Member of the carrot family, up to 80cm tall. Lower leaves dark-green, cut into 4-12 pairs of spear-shaped, blunt-toothed leaflets, and with a terminal leaf segment. Flowers small, white-petalled, and arranged in umbels of a few (often 3-5) rays of unequal length. The whole plant smells of parsley. This species can be confused with stone parsley Sison amomum whose foliage, when crushed, has an unpleasant smell of petrol, and whose umbels are made up of more or less equally-long rays, but often include a single much shorter ray.

Annual plant, up to 15cm tall, with much-branched, ascending to erect stems. Leaves oval, broadest above the middle, i.e. closer to the tip than to the base. Lower leaves look like they are arranged in whorls of four up the stem. Flowers small, 2-3mm across. Petals white, only 1mm long, and shorter than the green sepals. The flowers are clustered at the end of the stem. The best location to find four-leaved allseed is on the Isles of Scilly, but there are also populations in southwestern and southern parts of the English mainland.

description: Spreading plant with branched stems, up to 30cm tall. Leaves elongated-oval, broadest above the middle. All leaves have papery white sheaths (so-called ochreae) at their base. These are about 10mm long and form a tube around the stem. Flowers are borne singly or in pairs in leaf axils, with petals being pinkish. The distinctive fruits are greater than 3mm to 4.5mm long. Northern knotgrass is the commonest species of knotgrass present on Orkney and Shetland, but can be confused with other, similar-looking knotgrasses.
soil: Sandy soils, calcareous loams and clays.

description: Spreading plant with branched stems, up to 30cm tall. Leaves linear-lanceolate, 15-35mm long and 2-4mm wide, with acute tips. All leaves have papery white sheaths (so-called ochreae) at their base. These are about 10mm long and form a tube around the stem. Flowers borne singly or in pairs in leaf axils. with pinkish petals. The distinctive fruits are 2.5-4.5mm long, with three concave sides, and project beyond the flower. Cornfield knotgrass is under-recorded, due to difficulties in distinguishing it from other knotgrasses.
soil: Sandy soils, calcareous loams and clays.

description: Branched plant, up to 50cm tall. Leaves stalked, 3-5 lobed, deeply-divided, more elongated and linear than the leaves of common grassland buttercups. Upper stem lvs short-stalked, with few linear segments. Characteristic  buttercup flowers, but smaller, up to 12mm in diameter, and pale lemon-yellow. Seeds very distinctive, up to 8mm in length, ovate, and covered in spines up to 2mm in length. Increased use of broad-spectrum herbicides and of nitrogen fertiliserm and the planting of more competitive, nitrogen-demanding crops have resulted in a decline of this species.
seed_longevity: Short-lived seed unless deeply-buried where it may survive dormant for longer

Seeds distinctive, 7-8mm long, with a hooked beak at the tip, and covered in long hard spines, with one spine-free edge. Seeds round, 2-3mm in size, and lacking spines, but may have a few warts.

Fruits with 3-8 weakly-ribbed, bead-like joints which easily break apart when ripe, and a beak about five times as long as the topmost joint.

Flower tube formed by sepals which are pointed, straight, grey-green with narrow white margins, and which enclose the stamens and ovary. Annual knawel is commonly found on disturbed grassland as well as on arable land, but does not compete well within dense swards or underneath cereal crop canopies.
soil: Dry sandy and gravelly soils, clay loams and chalky loams.

description: Plant up to 30cm tall, branched, sticky-haired. Basal rosette of narrowly-oval leaves, which usually have already died off at the time of flowering. Smaller narrow leaves on the stem. Flowers white or occasionally pink, less than 1.2cm across. Petals with a slight notch. Seed capsules oval, about 1cm long. Small-flowered catchfly was once widespread, but it is poorly competitive, and thus not compatible with the growing of modern crop varieties. In addition, it is susceptible to a wide range of herbicides. Its remaining sites are generally coastal, in south-west England and Wales.

Up to 50cm tall, branched, and sticky-haired. Basal rosette made up of 5-10cm long elliptical leaves, which usually have already died off at the time of flowering. Stem leaves smaller, up to 8cm long. Flowers 2cm across, five-petalled, white to pink, and creamy-yellow on the outside. Each petal is deeply cut into two lobes. The flowers are tightly-rolled by mid-morning, and open again in the early evening, for pollination by nocturnal flying insects. Seed capsules oval, approximately 1.5mm long.

The beak (tip) of the fruit is flat and sabre-like, and as long or longer than the lower two-valved part with the seeds.

description: Mint family member with a much-branched, erect, leafy stem, growing up to 30cm tall. The whole plant is hairy. Flowers are arranged in whorls in leaf axils. Cut-leaved germander has always been rare and is only known from six locations in Surrey, Kent, Hampshire and Gloucestershire. It is a very poor competitor, with particularly poor persistence within stands of modern cereal varieties.

description: Up to 50cm tall annual, and member of the carrot family. Leaves greyish-green and pointed, divided into several pairs of lance-shaped leaflets, which are further divided or deeply cut into segments or teeth, and covered in short bristles, giving a frosted appearance. Flowers white or pinkish, borne in dense, compound heads. The characteristic 4-6mm long fruit are covered with numerous hooked spines. Spreading hedge-parsley was once widespread, but has declined dramatically, due to being a poor competitor with modern crop varieties, and due to changes in agriculture, involving harvesting and cultivation prior to seed-setting of this seasonally late-fruiting plant. Spreading hedge-parsley has persisted at isolated sites from Devon to Suffolk, and the species is most frequent in Somerset and East Anglia.

description: Highly localised Breckland species with one outlying population in Oxfordshire. This species has erect, sometimes branched, flowering stems, and is up to 20cm tall. The leaves are toothed, but not deeply divided. Flowers are small, about 3mm in diameter, and coloured light blue with dark streaks. They grow on stalks originating from leaf-like bracts along the top part of the stem. The fruit capsule is bi-lobed, giving it a heart-shaped appearance, and longer than wide.

Low-growing, erect to ascending, occasionally branched plant, up to 15cm tall. Leaves up to 1cm long, and deeply divided into 3-7 parallel-fingered lobes. Lower leaves with short stalks, upper leaves stalkless. Flowers deep blue, shorter than the surrounding calyx, and borne on comparatively short flower stalks originating in the axils of the leaf-like upper bracts. The fruit capsule is bi-lobed, giving it a heart-shaped appearance, 6-7mm long, and about as broad as long. Fingered speedwell is restricted to Breckland and Yorkshire.

Up to 15cm tall, erect plant, with simple or sometimes branched stems. Leaves are pinnetely-lobed with 5-7 segments. Flowers sky-blue, only 2-3mm across, and borne in the axils of 4-7mm long, leaf-like, bracts. The fruit capsule is bi-lobed, giving it a heart-shaped appearance, and wider than long. Spring speedwell is a highly localised species found in the Brecklands.

Scrambling annual, up to 60cm tall. The leaves are divided into 2-5 pairs of leaflets of about 1.5-2.5cm length. Flowers are pale purple and 6-8mm long, borne on long stalks. Calyx at the base of the flower with unequal teeth, with the upper two being shorter than the calyx tube. Each flower gives rise to a 5-8 seeded pod about 3mm wide. The scar on the seed surface, indicating where the seed was attached to the pod, is almost circular, whereas in smooth tare Vicia tetrasperma, it is about twice as long as wide. Slender tare occurs in the South Midlands, Somerset, Dorset, Oxfordshire and Essex, and has become much rarer recently.
soil: Calcareous clay loams and rarely on chalk.

description: Hairless annual plant with leaves divided into 3-6 pairs of leaflets of about 1-2cm length. Flowers mauve-whitish flowers. Calyx at the base of the flower with unequal teeth, with the upper two being shorter than the calyx tube. The seed pod is oblong, hairless, 12-15mm long and has four seeds. The scar on the seed surface, indicating where the seed was attached to the pod, is about twice as long as wide, whereas in slender tare Vicia parviflora, it is about twice as long as wide.

description: Resembles a garden pansy. Plant erect, branched, sometimes up to 40cm tall. Leaves very variable in shape, usually oval at the bottom of the stem, and becoming narrower towards the top of the stem. At the base of each leaf, there are large, leafy stipules. Flowers asymmetrical, with a short spur, 15-25mm top to bottom, and with long flowering stems. The face of the flower is flat, and the lower petals are cream coloured, the centre is yellow and the upper petals are pale-blue or purple. Sepals shorter than the petals, and enclosing the seed capsule after flowering. Wild pansy can be confused with field pansy Viola arvensis, whose flowers are smaller and cupped, with cream upper petals, and with sepals that are longer than the petals. The two species can hybridise with each other.
